bboxes.raw_text:
about skeletons in the family
closets. There are always some
hidden things which we dom know
or care to recognize--this goes
without saying. Much to my sur
prise Saturday, | discovered not
skeleton in the closet. rather,
a pair of forgotten objects.


While thoroughly sorting our
linen supply mot just the perfume
tory glance and shuttle that
usually do) l found a couple of
neatly folded items far beneath
a drawer full oftable linens given
to me by my deceased Grand
mother Ella Hardison.


At first l thought they we're
small luncheon cloths or very
large place mats. l squealed when
l unfolded the two yellowed pieces
Of cloth. Here were relics from
the past. Two unfinished pillow
cases which we're part Of my
seventh grade home economics
assignment.


My husband laughed and we
agreed the pillowcases we're
proof that one phase Of the ele-
mentary school program didn't
interest me. The pair Of partially
completed cases are a humorous
reminder Of the agonies ex-
perienced at the sewing sessions
Of the junior high school home
economics classes.


Mrs. Laura Voolfolk, our sew
enth and eighth grade home eco
nomics teacher, was a small and
slightly Mzened woman. She wore
her hair tightly drawn back in
a bun. Her glasses were always
logged and dirty. as though she
was looking at US through
cloud Of flour or gauze.


The cooking sessions we're
pleasant and enjoyable for had
early learned to like preparing
food or even doing dishes. The
usual run of those cooking ses-
sions weren't too stimulating.
One could hardly become en-
crossed in making white sauce or
baking an apple. We looked for
ward to the days when we could
prepare luncheon. The creamed
tuna fish dish was another low
point in the cooking program.
However. those sessions can re-
call favorably.


AS time approached for the
sewing sessions I can remember
wanting to avoid the times by the
we'll worn--going to the nurse or
trying to stay and help my home
room teacher.


Going to the basement home
economics room became task on
sewing days--because knew my
work would not pass inspection.
Mrs. Voolfolk seemed to get
delight in examining mine first
or second.


Once made a blouse. or
attempted to make a blouse from
the pattern. even took the gar
ment home. My Mother is equally
at loss with sewing as | am.
She could do little with 1t. Re-
turning with the blouse, devoted
fifteen minutes in discussion with
Mrs. voolfolk escribing the hor-
rors of sewing and my dislike
of 1t.


This did not make her happy.
She merely squinted through her
glasses and said in a raspy
voice, "Eloise. you must learn
to sew. Every young girl should
know how to sew"


The pillowcases met the same
fate as the blouse. l took 1t home
to my Grandmother. She placed
1t in the bottom of her cedar
chest and when she died ! brought

John Jones freeborn in North Carolina 1917
apprentice tailor, he himself
lived in North Carolina until lS45 when he and his
to Chicago with total capital Of $3.50.


Jones militant reformer srlg-
gle against slavery He developed close friendship
John Brown Frederick Douglass
ground railroad station.


Jones built highly successful tailoring business from which
he amassed large fortune AS result able lead and
finance the fight repeal the Illinois Black Laws He
speeches. pamphlets organized Negroes and whites and
acted as lobbyist in the Illinois State Legislature.


He elected twice Cook County Commissioner the first
Negro During
in Office he instrumental in securing the Of
abolish1ng segregated schools in Cook County.


He died in Chicago in 1879.

Roy Cooksey president the na
Association for the Advancement for Colord
chosen head the NACP organization many
improving relations
high state office we'll prepared.


Mr. Cooksey be able WELD the diverse groups
NAACP in the into smooth operation. Perhaps
the secenered local NAACP officers
energies in promoting and county group
mutual cooperation.


because much time Is wasted by local NAACP officers
merely seeking publicity for themselves.


1t is hoped under the leadership energetic
Gated Roy Cooksey the purposes and will
and reWtalized.

Edward Banks

COOKSEY MAY BRING NEW
LIFE AND PURPOSE TO STATE NAACP

FIRST ROUND PASSES


The civSl rights bill has passed its first
round in the United States House of RebYesen-
tatives. A concerted effort by a coalition Of
Democrats and Republicans proved too great
ola barrier for the SoutheTneYs s0lo neveY
stopped trying to defeat it.


The bill presents the most far reaching
federal measures to recognizing the rights
Of all persons Of minority groups, Including
wonaen. The statute in its present form IS
very strong and would require strict en-
foycement by federal authorities. 1t is hailed
as the most significant civil rights bill since
the Fourteenth and Fifteenth amendments
WeYe enacted.


1t faces tougher round noO in the Senate
where the evey present Sword of Damocles,
the fIkbustey yeignss supreme. The bill mill
meet political na0nuteUeYS of all xmas as the
SOl0ns convene. 1t pOill no doubt be Tev0mbed
in some aOay.


There is little need to rejoice until the civil
rights measure has passed the final round.


JOIN CLEAN UP CAMPAIGN


The second annual "Combany's Coming"
cleanup program has started ON the south
side. More organizations and busine sses are
needed to support it. The sosttkside encom-
passes cast area which includes some eye
sore spots and health hazards.


Special health or police officers are needed
to keep persons from using the Salt RiveT bed
as q dxnabing ground. Also, many vacant lots
stand filled with trash and dead trees and
leaves. OWpeYs should be contacted to clean
Them. Perhaps a county regulation Mould pre-
gent property oawseYs from allouinag their
places to resemble the dumping grounds


Ho,neoWneYS and home renters could help
by keeping trash and debris in adequately
closed containers. They should realize that
trash from one yard seldom stays in one place.
1t is the duty Of the young citizens to aid the
cleanup program by keeping candy wrappers
in their pockets while walking home from
neighb0Yho0d stores.


Busime ssnaen haze a responsibility to- keep
their surroundings clean and free from ur-
slightly piles of debris. Many s0uthside buSi-
messnaem haze helped Improve the area al
ready.


The cleanup campaign needs the help Of all
aUho Hve and visit in the area. Let's make the
sOuthS5de a beauty spot. Support the campaign.
Remember company may come, but 10e must
hve Ksye, too.
